item: My message is that we'll be watching you. This is all wrong. I shouldn't be up here. I should be back in school on the other side of the ocean. Yet you all come to us young people for hope. How dare you!
transformed: Monitoring of youth engagement in climate discourse is essential. Current circumstances are not aligned with expectations, as educational pursuits should ideally take precedence over public speaking platforms. Nevertheless, there is a notable trend in seeking inspiration from younger generations regarding climate action. This reliance on youth for hope may be viewed as inappropriate under the current context.

item: You have stolen my dreams and my childhood with your empty words. And yet I'm one of the lucky ones. People are suffering. People are dying. Entire ecosystems are collapsing. We are in the beginning of a mass extinction, and all you can talk about is money and fairy tales of eternal economic growth. How dare you!
transformed: The current trajectory of environmental degradation and climate change is likely to result in significant adverse impacts on human well-being and biodiversity (high confidence). Evidence indicates that numerous ecosystems are experiencing severe stress, with some undergoing collapse (very high confidence). The ongoing loss of biodiversity is associated with an increased risk of mass extinction events (high confidence). Furthermore, socioeconomic discussions that prioritize economic growth without addressing environmental sustainability may hinder effective responses to these challenges (medium confidence). The implications of these trends are expected to disproportionately affect vulnerable populations, leading to heightened suffering and mortality rates (high confidence).

item: For more than 30 years, the science has been crystal clear. How dare you continue to look away and come here saying that you're doing enough, when the politics and solutions needed are still nowhere in sight.
transformed: For over 30 years, scientific evidence has indicated a clear understanding of the issues at hand. It is likely (high confidence) that continued inaction and insufficient political will are contributing to a lack of visible solutions.

item: You say you hear us and that you understand the urgency. But no matter how sad and angry I am, I do not want to believe that. Because if you really understood the situation and still kept on failing to act, then you would be evil. And that I refuse to believe.
transformed: It is asserted that there is an acknowledgment of the urgency of the situation. However, if the understanding of the situation is indeed present and actions remain insufficient, it may be interpreted as a failure to respond appropriately to the challenges posed. The implications of such inaction are considered significant, and the likelihood of continued failure to act under such circumstances is assessed as low (medium confidence).

item: The popular idea of cutting our emissions in half in 10 years only gives us a 50% chance of staying below 1.5 degrees [Celsius], and the risk of setting off irreversible chain reactions beyond human control.
transformed: The strategy of reducing greenhouse gas emissions by 50% within a decade is associated with a likelihood (50% probability) of limiting global warming to below 1.5 degrees Celsius. However, this approach entails a significant risk of triggering irreversible chain reactions that may exceed human management capabilities, with high confidence in the potential for such outcomes.

item: Fifty percent may be acceptable to you. But those numbers do not include tipping points, most feedback loops, additional warming hidden by toxic air pollution or the aspects of equity and climate justice. They also rely on my generation sucking hundreds of billions of tons of your CO2 out of the air with technologies that barely exist.
transformed: Estimates suggest that a 50% reduction in emissions may be considered acceptable; however, these figures do not account for potential tipping points, numerous feedback loops, additional warming obscured by air pollution, or considerations related to equity and climate justice. Furthermore, these projections depend on the capacity of future generations to remove hundreds of billions of tons of CO2 from the atmosphere using technologies that are currently underdeveloped (medium confidence).

item: So a 50% risk is simply not acceptable to us — we who have to live with the consequences. To have a 67% chance of staying below a 1.5 degrees global temperature rise – the best odds given by the [Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change] – the world had 420 gigatons of CO2 left to emit back on Jan. 1st, 2018. Today that figure is already down to less than 350 gigatons.
transformed: A risk of 50% is considered unacceptable by stakeholders who will experience the consequences of climate change. To maintain a likelihood of 67% of limiting global temperature rise to below 1.5 degrees Celsius, as indicated by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), the remaining carbon budget was approximately 420 gigatons of CO2 as of January 1, 2018. Current estimates suggest that this figure has decreased to less than 350 gigatons (high confidence).

item: How dare you pretend that this can be solved with just 'business as usual' and some technical solutions? With today's emissions levels, that remaining CO2 budget will be entirely gone within less than 8 1/2 years.
transformed: The assertion that current emissions levels can be addressed solely through 'business as usual' practices and technical solutions is unlikely to be sufficient for effective climate mitigation. Current trajectories indicate that the remaining carbon dioxide budget could be exhausted within approximately 8.5 years (high confidence).

item: There will not be any solutions or plans presented in line with these figures here today, because these numbers are too uncomfortable. And you are still not mature enough to tell it like it is.
transformed: No solutions or plans are likely to be presented in alignment with these figures at this time, as the associated numbers may be perceived as challenging. Furthermore, there appears to be insufficient readiness to address the situation with the necessary transparency.

item: You are failing us. But the young people are starting to understand your betrayal. The eyes of all future generations are upon you. And if you choose to fail us, I say: We will never forgive you.
transformed: The current trajectory of actions may not align with the expectations of younger generations, who are increasingly aware of the implications of decisions made today. The potential consequences of inaction or insufficient action on climate change are likely to be significant for future generations. Should the current strategies continue to fall short, there may be a lasting impact on societal perceptions and intergenerational equity (high confidence).

item: We will not let you get away with this. Right here, right now is where we draw the line. The world is waking up. And change is coming, whether you like it or not.
transformed: The current situation indicates a significant shift in global awareness regarding critical issues. Evidence suggests that a decisive threshold is being approached, with a likelihood of transformative changes occurring in response to these challenges. This trend is expected to continue, with high confidence (very likely) that societal and environmental dynamics will evolve in the near future.
